com.itko.lisa.stats

Class MetricData

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.itko.lisa.stats.MetricData
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable

    public class MetricData
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable
    This is a data maintenance class that could have been no more than a List of Lists, but there's a big catch. This class keeps a logical table but allows updates one cell at a time. The other boring tables make you add a row at a time and don't support null values for those "I don't know that value yet" cases. That won't work in our case, so this exists. It has reasonably generic logic regarding how to handle missing data situations. See comments for more on addValue() and fillListWithValues for more.
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

        public MetricData(org.w3c.dom.Element parentEl)
        This will construct a MetricData from an XML document. Send the parent Node/Element of the whole thing, and we'll take it from there. I wouldn't use this MetricData instance to any any new collection work w/o testing that first...
        Parameters:
        parentEl - the parent XML element, like the docElement in most cases.

      • getValueRangeGuageRecent

        Parameters:

        Returns:

      • getValueRangeCounter

        public double[] getValueRangeCounter(java.lang.Object metric)
        This method will scan all the intervals that have been created for the given metic and return a array of the lowest and highest average values thus far Metrics that are of the Counter variety will want this calc more than the Guage type. The reason is b/c it automatically adjusts to the corrected value of just that interval. That is, it is the distance covered number, not the average of all collected values, that is calculated on.
        Parameters:
        metric -
        Returns:
        2-dim array of the lowest value and the highest value

      • getValueRangeCounterRecent

        public double[] getValueRangeCounterRecent(java.lang.Object metric)
        This method will scan all the recentm metrics that have been created for the given metic and return a array of the lowest and highest average values thus far
        Parameters:
        metric -
        Returns:
        2-dim array of the lowest value and the highest value

      • getMetricHandleList

        public java.util.List getMetricHandleList()
        If you get handed a MetricData object and have no idea what metrics are being collected, you can call this method to get a list of the handles we are tracking. BTW, there is nothing even remotely useful outside of this class in the metric's handle. The guy that called addMetric() and got the metric handle back is the only one who can properly associate the handle to something else. We are a completely indiscrimiate table in that we don't pretend to know what we're tracking.
        Returns:
        List of Objects that are handles into the Metrics list

      • addMetric

        public java.lang.Object addMetric(java.lang.String uniqName)
        This method is called to create a logical "column" if you will to store data in via subsequent calls to setValue(). This gives the class the early warning to have room to store this column of data.
        Returns:
        an opaque Object handle that is used as a key to this data

      • addValue

        public void addValue(java.lang.Object metric,
            java.lang.Object value)
        How you append your metric's data to the logical table. If this metric fills the table quicker than others, it will be adding new logical rows. If it does not add as quickly, then any missed rows will be set with this value as well. For example, if a metric has 2 more rows than this one already, then this method will add set the value of the 2 existing rows in the table, not add a new row. If there's already a value in the last row in the table, a new row is added and this is that row/column intersect's value.
        Parameters:
        metric - handle of the metric to add the value for
        value - the value to store

      • getCurrentValue

        public java.lang.Object getCurrentValue(java.lang.Object metric)
        Gets the most recently added value for a given metric
        Parameters:
        metric - what metric you want the value for
        Returns:
        the value last added

      • getValueFromBottom

        public java.lang.Object getValueFromBottom(java.lang.Object metric,
                                  int rowsBack)
        Gets the value for the given metric a given number of rows up from the bottom. For example, to get the most current, send 0, to get the 3rd from the last, send 3
        Parameters:
        metric - what metric you want the value for
        rowsBack - how far back you want to go for the value
        Returns:
        the value added

      • size

        public int size()
        This is the size of the logical table. It is possible that there are columns that do not yet have values all to way to this number of rows. When calling getCurrentValue() and fillListWithValues(), we'll reuse the last value we did get in any missing rows.
        Returns:
        size of the logical table

      • fillListWithValues

        public void fillListWithValues(java.util.List list,
                      java.lang.Object metric,
                      int rows)
        A convenience method for filling a List with the most recent 'rows' number of values for the given metric.
        Parameters:
        list - - the List you want filled, I will CLEAR its contents and replace it with 'rows' number of elements
        metric - - the metric whose values you want
        rows - - how many values you want

      • saveMetrics

        public void saveMetrics(boolean asXML,
               java.io.PrintWriter ps,
               java.util.List msiList,
               java.lang.String runName)
        Writes the current set of metrics (this is everything we have collected since the last interval was reached). Note that we purposely keep up to 2 intervals worth of data as current.
        Parameters:
        asXML - write as XML or CSV?
        ps - stream to persist into
        msiList - list of Metric objects to save
        runName - the run name for this (some methods have a place to save this)
